title: Kenya: City Must Move Fast On Transport Project
text:
Kenya: NTSA Suspend 40 Hannover Bus Licences 
An organised commuter bus system linking all parts of the greater metropolis to replace the current system of lawless matatus must be taken as a priority. 
Light rail and tram services criss-crossing Nairobi and linking the city to the neighbouring counties of Machakos, Kiambu, Murang'a and Kajiado are also an imperative. 
The Mass Rapid Transit System should be adopted as a flagship project under the Vision 2030 programme and given all the necessary resources. 
Generous support promised by the Government of Japan should help a great deal towards seeing the project off the ground. 
However, what might matter even more is how fast the various central government ministries and county administrations involved can move with focus and harmony towards a shared goal. 
The way the traffic and commuter transport in Nairobi has been allowed to deteriorate, placing commuters at the mercy of cartels and allowing chaotic gridlocks right in the central business district, does not inspire confidence. 
It might, therefore, be necessary to bring in experts from modern cities elsewhere to help drive the project. Kenya
